elements.content: Single crystals of the mononuclear bis-oxamate nickel(II) complex [Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)]·dmso (1) are obtained by reacting [Ni(bipy)Cl2]·H2O and the flexible K2(H2edpba) ligand [bipy = 2,2′-bipyridine; H4edpba = N,N′-2,2′-ethylenediphenylenebis(oxamic acid)]. The reaction of 1 with copper(II) ions resulted in two products in which the replacement of the nickel(II) ion by copper(II) took place: the chain compound [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ·3nH2O·ndmso [dmso = dimethyl sulfoxide] (2) and the analogous chain compound without dmso crystallization molecules [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ·1.5nH2O (3a) in its polycrystalline form. The reaction of [Cu(bipy)Cl2] and K2(H2edpba) yielded single crystals of [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ·1.5nH2O (3b). The H2edpba2– ligand exhibits the anti conformation in 1, 2, and 3b, but it adopts different coordination modes: terminal bis-bidentate (1) and bridging bis-bidentate (2 and 3b) through the two pairs of carbonyl-oxygen atoms of the two oxamate arms. Magnetic susceptibility measurements carried out on a polycrystalline sample of 3b in the temperature range 1.9–295 K showed the occurrence of very weak intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions [J = −0.40 cm–1, the Hamiltonian being defined as H = −J ∑ i S i · S i+1], in agreement with the large values of the copper–copper separation [8.308(3) Å].

The reaction of 1 with copper(II) ions resulted in two products in which the replacement of the nickel(II) ion by copper(II) took place: the chain compound [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅3nH2O⋅ndmso [dmso = dimethyl sulfoxide] (2) and the analogous chain compound without dmso crystallization molecules [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅1.5nH2O (3a) in its polycrystalline form. The reaction of [Cu(bipy)Cl2] and K2(H2edpba) yielded single crystals of [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅1.5nH2O (3b). The H2edpba2- ligand exhibits the anti conformation in 1, 2, and 3b, but it adopts different coordination modes: terminal bis-bidentate (1) and bridging bis-bidentate (2 and 3b) through the two pairs of carbonyl-oxygen atoms of the two oxamate arms. Magnetic susceptibility measurements carried out on a polycrystalline sample of 3b in the temperature range 1.9-295 K showed the occurrence of very weak intrachain antiferromagnetic interactions [J = -0.40 cm-1, the Hamiltonian being defined as  H  = -J ∑ i   S   i ⋅ S   i+1], in agreement with the large values of the copper-copper separation [8.308(3) Å].

elements.content:
In this paper we present three examples of the molecular architecture driven by metal ion self-assembly.

Introduction

The control of supramolecular architectures by handling the molecules in the solid state is one of the major challenges faced by chemists working with crystal engineering. Because the single crystal is a supramolecular structure by design, the control of several parameters that lead to the crystallization of the desired product involves clever strategies and many trials, ranging from the choice of the appropriate building blocks to the control of the conditions for synthesis. The effective manipulation of the solid state covalent interactions and supramolecular forces into the crystal (i.e., van der Waals interactions, hydrogen bonds, and π–π stacking) is desired by synthetic chemists dealing with crystal engineering. The literature is enriched by several publications full of notable examples in this field to guide synthetic chemists.

Introduction

The control of supramolecular architectures by handling the molecules in the solid state is one of the major challenges faced by chemists working with crystal engineering. Because the single crystal is a supramolecular structure by design, the control of several parameters that lead to the crystallization of the desired product involves clever strategies and many trials, ranging from the choice of the appropriate building blocks to the control of the conditions for synthesis. The effective manipulation of the solid state covalent interactions and supramolecular forces into the crystal (i.e., van der Waals interactions, hydrogen bonds, and π-π stacking) is desired by synthetic chemists dealing with crystal engineering. The literature is enriched by several publications full of notable examples in this field to guide synthetic chemists.

elements.content: In our studies, we have worked with several bis(oxamate) building blocks that exhibit a great versatility as both terminal and bridging ligands, with the main aim being the rational preparation of molecule-based magnets. Several molecular architectures, coordination networks, or coordination polymers (CPs) of one, two, or three dimensions with different magnetic properties can be built through the self-assembly of these building blocks. In the molecules-to-materials approach, particularly when attempting to make a switch or sensor, the magnetic properties associated with the bistability phenomena involving phase transitions triggered by pH, light, temperature, solvent, and templating ions, among other examples, are envisaged. Recently, we have reported two examples of CPs containing oxamate ligands that exhibit single-crystal-to-single-crystal transitions. One of them, [Co(H2O)2Pd(opba)] n · ndmso [H4opba = N,N′-1,2-phenylenebis(oxamic acid)], exhibits a thermally triggered single-crystal-to-single-crystal phase transition, whereas in the other example, a pair of compounds, namely, the [Cu(bipy)(H2mpba)]2·2H2O building block and its isomeric chain [Cu(bipy)(H2mpba)] n ·ndmso [bipy = 2,2′-bipyridine and H4mpba = N,N′-1,3-phenylenebis(oxamic acid)], undergo a solvent driven interconversion.

Several molecular architectures, coordination networks, or coordination polymers (CPs) of one, two, or three dimensions with different magnetic properties can be built through the self-assembly of these building blocks. In the molecules-to-materials approach, particularly when attempting to make a switch or sensor, the magnetic properties associated with the bistability phenomena involving phase transitions triggered by pH, light, temperature, solvent, and templating ions, among other examples, are envisaged. Recently, we have reported two examples of CPs containing oxamate ligands that exhibit single-crystal-to-single-crystal transitions. One of them, [Co(H2O)2Pd(opba)] n  ⋅ ndmso [H4opba = N,N'-1,2-phenylenebis(oxamic acid)], exhibits a thermally triggered single-crystal-to-single-crystal phase transition, whereas in the other example, a pair of compounds, namely, the [Cu(bipy)(H2mpba)]2⋅2H2O building block and its isomeric chain [Cu(bipy)(H2mpba)] n ⋅ndmso [bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine and H4mpba = N,N'-1,3-phenylenebis(oxamic acid)], undergo a solvent driven interconversion.

elements.content: In this paper, we describe the preparation and structural characterization of three compounds containing the flexible bis(oxamate) ligand N,N′-2,2′-ethylenediphenylenebis(oxamate) (H2edpba2–): (i) the mononuclear [Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)] (1) complex; (ii) two CPs of formula [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ·3nH2O·ndmso [dmso = dimethyl sulfoxide] (2) and [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ·1.5nH2O (3a), in which the former is obtained as single crystals and the latter is obtained as a polycrystalline solid, and both result from the replacement of the nickel(II) ion in 1 by copper(II) in the direct addition synthesis; and (iii) single crystals of the chain [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ·1.5nH2O (3b), which are obtained by a slow diffusion technique (see Scheme ).

elements.content: 2,2′-Bipyridine (Acros Organics), copper(II) chloride dihydrate and dimethyl sulfoxide (Sigma-Aldrich), nickel(II) chloride hexahydrate (Stream Chemicals), tetrahydrofuran and potassium hydroxide (Merck) were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. The diethyl ester proligand Et2H2edpba was prepared according to a previously reported procedure. The K2(H2edpba) salt was synthesized as follows: KOH (0.804 g, 12.2 mmol) was poured into an aqueous suspension of Et2H2edpba (2.53 g, 6.1 mmol) under continuous stirring for 30 min at 60 °C; the desired salt as a white polycrystalline powder is obtained by removal of the solvent in a rotator evaporator. Calcd for C18H14K2N2O6: C, 49.99; H, 3.26; N, 6.48. Found: C, 48.97; H, 3.41; N, 6.53%. The precursor [Ni(bipy)Cl2]·H2O was synthesized as follows: NiCl2·6H2O (1.183 g, 5.0 mmol) was poured into a THF solution of bipy (0.781 g, 5.0 mmol) under continuous stirring for 30 min; the removal of the solvent in a rotator evaporator afforded this compound as a bluish green solid. Yield: 98%. Calcd for C10H10Cl2N2NiO: C, 39.54; H, 3.32; N, 9.22; Cu, 19.32. Found: C, 39.33; H, 3.42; N, 8.99; Cu, 19.63%. [Cu(bipy)Cl2] was prepared as follows: CuCl2·2H2O (0.852 g, 5.0 mmol) was poured into a THF solution of bipy (0.781 g, 5.0 mmol) under continuous stirring for 30 min; the desired precursor precipitated as a bluish green powder, which was filtered, washed with THF, and air-dried. Yield: 99%. Calcd for C10H8N2Cl2Cu: C, 41.33; H, 2.77; N, 9.64; Cu, 21.86. Found: C, 40.89; H, 2.87; N, 9.28; Cu, 20.11%.

Experimental Section

Materials

2,2'-Bipyridine (Acros Organics), copper(II) chloride dihydrate and dimethyl sulfoxide (Sigma-Aldrich), nickel(II) chloride hexahydrate (Stream Chemicals), tetrahydrofuran and potassium hydroxide (Merck) were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. The diethyl ester proligand Et2H2edpba was prepared according to a previously reported procedure. The K2(H2edpba) salt was synthesized as follows: KOH (0.804 g, 12.2 mmol) was poured into an aqueous suspension of Et2H2edpba (2.53 g, 6.1 mmol) under continuous stirring for 30 min at 60 °C; the desired salt as a white polycrystalline powder is obtained by removal of the solvent in a rotator evaporator. Calcd for C18H14K2N2O6: C, 49.99; H, 3.26; N, 6.48. Found: C, 48.97; H, 3.41; N, 6.53%. The precursor [Ni(bipy)Cl2]⋅H2O was synthesized as follows: NiCl2⋅6H2O (1.183 g, 5.0 mmol) was poured into a THF solution of bipy (0.781 g, 5.0 mmol) under continuous stirring for 30 min; the removal of the solvent in a rotator evaporator afforded this compound as a bluish green solid. Yield: 98%. Calcd for C10H10Cl2N2NiO: C, 39.54; H, 3.32; N, 9.22; Cu, 19.32. Found: C, 39.33; H, 3.42; N, 8.99; Cu, 19.63%. [Cu(bipy)Cl2] was prepared as follows: CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.852 g, 5.0 mmol) was poured into a THF solution of bipy (0.781 g, 5.0 mmol) under continuous stirring for 30 min; the desired precursor precipitated as a bluish green powder, which was filtered, washed with THF, and air-dried. Yield: 99%. Calcd for C10H8N2Cl2Cu: C, 41.33; H, 2.77; N, 9.64; Cu, 21.86. Found: C, 40.89; H, 2.87; N, 9.28; Cu, 20.11%.

elements.content: The addition of [Ni(bipy)Cl2]·H2O (0.532 g, 1.75 mmol) dissolved in 50 mL of water to an aqueous solution (50 mL) of K2(H2edpba) (0.757 g, 1.75 mmol) produces a precipitate that was solubilized by adding 50 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide. The mixed solvent solution was set aside, and X-ray quality sky blue platelets were grown after 2 weeks from the standing solution kept at room temperature. Yield: 85%. Anal. Calcd for C32H34NiN4O8S2 (1): C, 55.66; H, 4.36; N, 8.66; Ni, 8.09. Found: C, 54.87; H, 4.42; N, 8.58; Ni, 8.26%. IR/cm–1: 3189 (N–H), 1670 and 1644 (CO), 1530 and 1445 (CN + CC), 1023 and 952 (SO).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Complexes. [Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)]⋅dmso (1)

The addition of [Ni(bipy)Cl2]⋅H2O (0.532 g, 1.75 mmol) dissolved in 50 mL of water to an aqueous solution (50 mL) of K2(H2edpba) (0.757 g, 1.75 mmol) produces a precipitate that was solubilized by adding 50 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide. The mixed solvent solution was set aside, and X-ray quality sky blue platelets were grown after 2 weeks from the standing solution kept at room temperature. Yield: 85%. Anal. Calcd for C32H34NiN4O8S2 (1): C, 55.66; H, 4.36; N, 8.66; Ni, 8.09. Found: C, 54.87; H, 4.42; N, 8.58; Ni, 8.26%. IR/cm-1: 3189 (N-H), 1670 and 1644 (CO), 1530 and 1445 (CN + CC), 1023 and 952 (SO).

elements.content: CuCl2·2H2O (0.416 g, 2.44 mmol) was added in small portions under continuous stirring to the solution described in the synthesis of 1. The clear green solution was allowed to concentrate at room temperature in a hood. Nonrepresentative pale green prismatic crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction experiments were collected from a green polycrystalline powder (3a) after 3 weeks. The structure of 2 was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The compound 3a was collected on filter paper and dried in the open air. Yield: 21%. Anal. Calcd for C28H26CuN4O8 (3a): C, 55.95; H, 4.19; N, 9.32; Cu, 10.57. Found: C, 55.81; H, 3.81; N, 9.19; Cu, 10.81%. IR/cm–1: 3490 and 3420 (O–H), 3360 and 3240 (N–H), 1678 and 1642 (CO), 1520 and 1440 (CN + CC).

[Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅3nH2O⋅ndmso (2) and [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅1.5nH2O (3a)

CuCl2⋅2H2O (0.416 g, 2.44 mmol) was added in small portions under continuous stirring to the solution described in the synthesis of 1. The clear green solution was allowed to concentrate at room temperature in a hood. Nonrepresentative pale green prismatic crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction experiments were collected from a green polycrystalline powder (3a) after 3 weeks. The structure of 2 was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The compound 3a was collected on filter paper and dried in the open air. Yield: 21%. Anal. Calcd for C28H26CuN4O8 (3a): C, 55.95; H, 4.19; N, 9.32; Cu, 10.57. Found: C, 55.81; H, 3.81; N, 9.19; Cu, 10.81%. IR/cm-1: 3490 and 3420 (O-H), 3360 and 3240 (N-H), 1678 and 1642 (CO), 1520 and 1440 (CN + CC).

elements.content: This compound was obtained as follows: [Cu(bipy)Cl2] (0.015 g, 0.052 mmol) dissolved in 2.0 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide was introduced in a test tube; then, 10 mL of a 1:1 dmso:water (v/v) mixture was slowly poured into the tube; finally, 2.0 mL of an aqueous solution of K2(H2edpba) (0.028 g, 0.065 mmol) was added dropwise. The resulting solution was allowed to diffuse at room temperature, and X-ray quality sky blue needles were grown after 4 weeks. Yield: 71%. Anal. Calcd for C28H26CuN4O8 (3b): C, 55.95; H, 4.19; N, 9.32; Cu, 10.57. Found: C, 56.08; H, 3.86; N, 9.28; Cu, 10.92%. IR/cm–1: 3490 and 3420 (O–H), 3360 and 3240 (N–H), 1678 and 1642 (CO), and 1520 and 1440 (CN + CC).
elements.clean_text:
[Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅1.5nH2O (3b)

This compound was obtained as follows: [Cu(bipy)Cl2] (0.015 g, 0.052 mmol) dissolved in 2.0 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide was introduced in a test tube; then, 10 mL of a 1:1 dmso:water (v/v) mixture was slowly poured into the tube; finally, 2.0 mL of an aqueous solution of K2(H2edpba) (0.028 g, 0.065 mmol) was added dropwise. The resulting solution was allowed to diffuse at room temperature, and X-ray quality sky blue needles were grown after 4 weeks. Yield: 71%. Anal. Calcd for C28H26CuN4O8 (3b): C, 55.95; H, 4.19; N, 9.32; Cu, 10.57. Found: C, 56.08; H, 3.86; N, 9.28; Cu, 10.92%. IR/cm-1: 3490 and 3420 (O-H), 3360 and 3240 (N-H), 1678 and 1642 (CO), and 1520 and 1440 (CN + CC).

elements.content: Elemental analyses (for C, H, N) were performed with a PerkinElmer 2400 analyzer. The nickel and copper contents were determined by atomic absorption spectrometry with a Hitachi Z-8200 polarized atomic absorption spectrophotometer. X-ray powder diffraction patterns were obtained by means of a Rigaku/Geirgeflex diffractometer working at room temperature. Diffraction data were collected in the Bragg/Brentano mode (deg s–1) using monochromatic Cu Kα radiation. The thermal study (TG/DTA) of polycrystalline samples of 1, 3a, and 3b was conducted on a Shimadzu TG-60 thermal analyzer by using ca. 3.0–5.0 mg of the product packed in an alumina crucible. The samples were heated at 10 °C min–1 from room temperature to 900 °C in a dynamic air atmosphere (flow rate = 50 cm3 min–1). Infrared spectra of 1, 3a, and 3b were recorded on a PerkinElmer FTIR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm–1 with an average of 128 scans and 4 cm–1 of spectral resolution. The magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on crystalline samples of 3a and 3b in the temperature range 1.9–295 K with a Quantum Design SQUID susceptometer and using applied magnetic fields of 0.1 T (T ≥ 100 K) and 250 G (T < 100 K). Diamagnetic corrections of the constituent atoms were estimated from Pascal’s constants as −274 × 10–6 cm3 mol–1 K (3a and 3b) per one mole of copper(II) ions. Experimental susceptibilities were also corrected for the temperature-independent paramagnetism [60 × 10–6 cm3 mol–1 per copper(II)] and the magnetization of the sample holder. X-band EPR spectra on polycrystalline samples of 3a and 3b were performed at 4.0 K using a Bruker ER 200 spectrometer equipped with a helium continuous-flow cryostat.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Elemental analyses (for C, H, N) were performed with a PerkinElmer 2400 analyzer. The nickel and copper contents were determined by atomic absorption spectrometry with a Hitachi Z-8200 polarized atomic absorption spectrophotometer. X-ray powder diffraction patterns were obtained by means of a Rigaku/Geirgeflex diffractometer working at room temperature. Diffraction data were collected in the Bragg/Brentano mode (deg s-1) using monochromatic Cu Kα radiation. The thermal study (TG/DTA) of polycrystalline samples of 1, 3a, and 3b was conducted on a Shimadzu TG-60 thermal analyzer by using ca. 3.0-5.0 mg of the product packed in an alumina crucible. The samples were heated at 10 °C min-1 from room temperature to 900 °C in a dynamic air atmosphere (flow rate = 50 cm3 min-1). Infrared spectra of 1, 3a, and 3b were recorded on a PerkinElmer FTIR spectrophotometer using KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1 with an average of 128 scans and 4 cm-1 of spectral resolution. The magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on crystalline samples of 3a and 3b in the temperature range 1.9-295 K with a Quantum Design SQUID susceptometer and using applied magnetic fields of 0.1 T (T ≥ 100 K) and 250 G (T < 100 K). Diamagnetic corrections of the constituent atoms were estimated from Pascal's constants as -274 × 10-6 cm3 mol-1 K (3a and 3b) per one mole of copper(II) ions. Experimental susceptibilities were also corrected for the temperature-independent paramagnetism [60 × 10-6 cm3 mol-1 per copper(II)] and the magnetization of the sample holder. X-band EPR spectra on polycrystalline samples of 3a and 3b were performed at 4.0 K using a Bruker ER 200 spectrometer equipped with a helium continuous-flow cryostat.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data for 1, 2, and 3b were performed on an Oxford-Diffraction GEMINI diffractometer by using graphite-Enhance Source Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Measurements were performed at different temperatures, as shown in Table . Data integration and scaling of the reflections for all compounds were carried out with the Crysalis suite of programs. Final unit cell parameters were based on the fitting of all reflection positions. Analytical absorption corrections were performed using the Crysalis suite of programs. The XPREP program was used in the identification of the space group.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination and Refinement

X-ray diffraction data for 1, 2, and 3b were performed on an Oxford-Diffraction GEMINI diffractometer by using graphite-Enhance Source Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). Measurements were performed at different temperatures, as shown in Table . Data integration and scaling of the reflections for all compounds were carried out with the Crysalis suite of programs. Final unit cell parameters were based on the fitting of all reflection positions. Analytical absorption corrections were performed using the Crysalis suite of programs. The XPREP  program was used in the identification of the space group.

The structures of 1, 2, and 3b were solved via direct methods using the SUPERFLIP program. For each compound, the positions of all atoms could be unambiguously assigned on consecutive difference Fourier maps. Solvent molecules were observed in the structures of all compounds. Refinements were performed by using SHELXL based on F 2 through a full-matrix least-squares routine. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic atomic displacement parameters. All but the water molecule hydrogen atoms were added in the respective structures at idealized positions and further refined according to the riding model. Distances of 0.97, 0.93, and 0.96 Å were constrained for C–H bonds of the methylene, methyl, and aromatic carbon atoms, respectively, with U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(C) and U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(C) for the methyl groups. Hydrogen atoms from water molecules were refined subject to O–H and H–O–H angle restraints with U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(O). The disordered dimethyl sulfoxide solvent in 1 was modeled using split atomic positions for all atoms and equal occupancy for atoms of each disordered molecule. One of the aromatic rings in the H2edpba2– ligand for 3b showed some remarkable positional disorder due to the spin from the aliphatic arm connecting them, and it was modeled using three split atomic positions and different occupancy factors of each disordered ring. Graphical manipulations were performed using the Mercury and DIAMOND programs. The crystal data and structure refinements of 1, 2, and 3b are listed in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles as well as the hydrogen bond parameters are given in Tables and . The Mercury software was also used to simulate the X-ray powder diffraction patterns from the atomic positions obtained from the single crystal structure analysis.

elements.content: The preparative pathways of the four compounds are shown in Scheme . [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ·3nH2O·ndmso (2) and [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ·1.5nH2O (3a) result from a H2O:dmso mixed solvent containing [Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ·ndmso (1) and CuCl2·2H2O because of the substitution of the nickel(II) ion by the copper(II) ion. However, 2 is not representative of the whole sample because the elemental analysis, infrared spectrum, and standard X-ray powder of the polycrystalline powder did not agree with the expected measures for the structure of 2. This leads us to suspect that 3a is the same coordination polymer with the absence of the dmso molecule of crystallization in this sample. Several attempts to prepare compound 3a in a straightforward manner by reacting the H2edpba2– and [Cu(bipy)]2+ entities afforded the coordination polymer [Cu(H2edpba)(bipy)] n ·1.5nH2O (3b). Although the elemental analysis, IR spectra, and XRD patterns for 3a and 3b indicate that they are the same compound (see ), their colors are slightly different: light green and light blue, respectively. The UV–vis spectra for the bulk of both compounds are almost identical, except for the shoulder near 400 nm in the spectrum of 3a (see ). This shoulder can be assigned to copper impurities originating from the direct excess addition of CuCl2·2H2O used in this synthesis. On the contrary, the slow diffusion of the precursors in the test tube led to a purer product. Thermal analyses support this hypothesis because of the greater amount of the 3a residue at 900 °C than the 3b residue (see ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and IR Spectroscopy

The preparative pathways of the four compounds are shown in Scheme . [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅3nH2O⋅ndmso (2) and [Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅1.5nH2O (3a) result from a H2O:dmso mixed solvent containing [Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅ndmso (1) and CuCl2⋅2H2O because of the substitution of the nickel(II) ion by the copper(II) ion. However, 2 is not representative of the whole sample because the elemental analysis, infrared spectrum, and standard X-ray powder of the polycrystalline powder did not agree with the expected measures for the structure of 2. This leads us to suspect that 3a is the same coordination polymer with the absence of the dmso molecule of crystallization in this sample. Several attempts to prepare compound 3a in a straightforward manner by reacting the H2edpba2- and [Cu(bipy)]2+ entities afforded the coordination polymer [Cu(H2edpba)(bipy)] n ⋅1.5nH2O (3b). Although the elemental analysis, IR spectra, and XRD patterns for 3a and 3b indicate that they are the same compound (see ), their colors are slightly different: light green and light blue, respectively. The UV-vis spectra for the bulk of both compounds are almost identical, except for the shoulder near 400 nm in the spectrum of 3a (see ). This shoulder can be assigned to copper impurities originating from the direct excess addition of CuCl2⋅2H2O used in this synthesis. On the contrary, the slow diffusion of the precursors in the test tube led to a purer product. Thermal analyses support this hypothesis because of the greater amount of the 3a residue at 900 °C than the 3b residue (see ).

elements.content: The IR spectrum of 1 exhibits the expected N–H amide of the dideprotonated H2edpba2– ligand at 3189 cm–1. The CO stretching vibration occurs at 1670 and 1644 cm–1. The bands in the 1530–1445 cm–1 region of the spectrum correspond to CN and CC stretching vibrations, which are characteristic of the aromatic rings of the bipy and H2edpba2– ligands. Moreover, two characteristic bands, most likely due to the stretching vibrations of dimethyl sulfoxide (SO), are observed at 1023 and 952 cm–1. The pattern of the bands for 3a and 3b is very similar, exhibiting a strong and broad absorption in the high-frequency region (3490–3420 cm–1) due to the O–H stretching of the crystallization water molecules and the expected N–H amide of the H2edpba2– ligand at 3360 and 3240 cm–1. The CO stretching vibrations are observed at 1678 and 1642 cm–1, and absorptions in the 1520–1440 cm–1 region are attributed to the CN and CC stretching frequencies from the aromatic rings of the bipy and H2edpba2– ligands in the CPs 3a and 3b. The spectroscopic features of 1, 3a, and 3b can be understood from the analysis of their crystal structures (see below).

The bands in the 1530-1445 cm-1 region of the spectrum correspond to CN and CC stretching vibrations, which are characteristic of the aromatic rings of the bipy and H2edpba2- ligands. Moreover, two characteristic bands, most likely due to the stretching vibrations of dimethyl sulfoxide (SO), are observed at 1023 and 952 cm-1. The pattern of the bands for 3a and 3b is very similar, exhibiting a strong and broad absorption in the high-frequency region (3490-3420 cm-1) due to the O-H stretching of the crystallization water molecules and the expected N-H amide of the H2edpba2- ligand at 3360 and 3240 cm-1. The CO stretching vibrations are observed at 1678 and 1642 cm-1, and absorptions in the 1520-1440 cm-1 region are attributed to the CN and CC stretching frequencies from the aromatic rings of the bipy and H2edpba2- ligands in the CPs 3a and 3b. The spectroscopic features of 1, 3a, and 3b can be understood from the analysis of their crystal structures (see below).

elements.content: The structure of 1 consists of neutral [Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)] units in a six-coordinate environment and dimethyl sulfoxide molecules of crystallization (Figure ). This compound crystallizes in a noncentrosymmetric orthorhombic space group P212121, and the asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent [Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)] complexes with different chiralities (Ni1-Δ and Ni2-Λ) and one disordered dimethyl sulfoxide molecule per complex. Each nickel(II) ion in 1 is six-coordinate with two nitrogen atoms from a bidentate bipy molecule and two pairs of carbonyl-oxygen atoms from a H2edpba2– ligand in a cis configuration; taken together, this arrangement builds a somewhat distorted octahedral NiN2O4 environment. The dideprotonated H2edpba2– ligand exhibits the anti conformation in 1, which is also maintained in 2 and 3b (see below).
elements.clean_text:
Description of the Structures

[Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)]⋅dmso (1)

The structure of 1 consists of neutral [Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)] units in a six-coordinate environment and dimethyl sulfoxide molecules of crystallization (Figure ). This compound crystallizes in a noncentrosymmetric orthorhombic space group P212121, and the asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent [Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)] complexes with different chiralities (Ni1-Δ and Ni2-Λ) and one disordered dimethyl sulfoxide molecule per complex. Each nickel(II) ion in 1 is six-coordinate with two nitrogen atoms from a bidentate bipy molecule and two pairs of carbonyl-oxygen atoms from a H2edpba2- ligand in a cis configuration; taken together, this arrangement builds a somewhat distorted octahedral NiN2O4 environment. The dideprotonated H2edpba2- ligand exhibits the anti conformation in 1, which is also maintained in 2 and 3b (see below).

elements.content: The crystal packing of 1 is assured by N–H···O and Car–H···O hydrogen bonds and π-stacking of the bipyridine groups from crystallographically independent [Ni(bipy)(H2edpba)] complexes forming a ribbon (Figure a), with the Car–H···O and N–H···Odmso hydrogen bonds linking the ribbons together (Figure S1, ). The amide-nitrogen from the H2edpba2– ligand is the H atom donor in both cases, and the acceptors are the free carboxylate-oxygen of each oxamate fragment of the H2edpba2– ligand and a sulfonyl oxygen atom of a dmso molecule (Table ). The hydrogen bonds are in the range of a weak intramolecular interaction varying from 2.767 to 2.838 Å. Additional contributions to the stabilization of the crystal packing arise from weak intermolecular interactions that involve the π-stacking between the aromatic rings of the bipy molecules (average distance of 3.69 Å). The hydrogen atoms from the bipy groups also exhibit weak edge-to-face interactions with an aromatic ring from the H2edpba2– ligand (∼2.7 Å) and very weak C–Hring···Odmso type interactions.

The amide-nitrogen from the H2edpba2- ligand is the H atom donor in both cases, and the acceptors are the free carboxylate-oxygen of each oxamate fragment of the H2edpba2- ligand and a sulfonyl oxygen atom of a dmso molecule (Table ). The hydrogen bonds are in the range of a weak intramolecular interaction varying from 2.767 to 2.838 Å. Additional contributions to the stabilization of the crystal packing arise from weak intermolecular interactions that involve the π-stacking between the aromatic rings of the bipy molecules (average distance of 3.69 Å). The hydrogen atoms from the bipy groups also exhibit weak edge-to-face interactions with an aromatic ring from the H2edpba2- ligand (~2.7 Å) and very weak C-Hring⋅⋅⋅Odmso type interactions.

elements.content: From a supramolecular chemistry point of view, the structure of 1 can be viewed as a 1D-like motif growing along the crystallographic b axis (Figure ). Within this supramolecular chain, the nickel(II) ions are separated by 10.194(2) Å, considering the direction in which the hydrogen bonds occur, and by 7.5127(19) Å, considering the direction in which the 2,2′-bipyridine π-stacking takes place (see the dashed lines in Figure ). Examining the two nearest supramolecular chains, each crystallographically independent nickel(II) ion is far from its symmetrically generated atom by 10.4695(19) Å (Ni1···Ni1i) and 10.5093(19) Å (Ni2···Ni2i) [symmetry code: (i) = x + 1/2, −y + 1/2, −z], with the shortest distance between the interchain metal–metal being 7.2602(17) Å (see Table ).
elements.clean_text: From a supramolecular chemistry point of view, the structure of 1 can be viewed as a 1D-like motif growing along the crystallographic b axis (Figure ). Within this supramolecular chain, the nickel(II) ions are separated by 10.194(2) Å, considering the direction in which the hydrogen bonds occur, and by 7.5127(19) Å, considering the direction in which the 2,2'-bipyridine π-stacking takes place (see the dashed lines in Figure ). Examining the two nearest supramolecular chains, each crystallographically independent nickel(II) ion is far from its symmetrically generated atom by 10.4695(19) Å (Ni1⋅⋅⋅Ni1i) and 10.5093(19) Å (Ni2⋅⋅⋅Ni2i) [symmetry code: (i) = x + 1/2, -y + 1/2, -z], with the shortest distance between the interchain metal-metal being 7.2602(17) Å (see Table ).

elements.content: This compound crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21 /c. The asymmetric unit contains a copper(II) ion surrounded by a chelating bipy molecule and two bidentate oxamate fragments from two crystallographically independent H2edpba2– ligands plus one disordered dmso and three water molecules of crystallization (Figure ). Each H2edpba2– ligand exhibits the anti conformation and acts like a bridge between the copper(II) ions through the carbonyl-oxygen atoms of the two oxamate fragments, leading to a neutral nonhelicoidal zigzag chain running parallel to the crystallographic a axis (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
[Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅3nH2O⋅ndmso (2)

This compound crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic space group P21 /c. The asymmetric unit contains a copper(II) ion surrounded by a chelating bipy molecule and two bidentate oxamate fragments from two crystallographically independent H2edpba2- ligands plus one disordered dmso and three water molecules of crystallization (Figure ). Each H2edpba2- ligand exhibits the anti conformation and acts like a bridge between the copper(II) ions through the carbonyl-oxygen atoms of the two oxamate fragments, leading to a neutral nonhelicoidal zigzag chain running parallel to the crystallographic a axis (Figure ).

elements.content: Each copper(II) ion in 2 exhibits a distorted six-coordinate environment and different chiralities [Cu1-Δ and Cu1i-Λ, (i) = 1/2 + x, 1/2 – y, 1/2 + z], with the two bipy-nitrogen atoms and the O2 and O5 carboxylate(oxamate)-oxygen atoms building the equatorial plane and the O1 and O6 amide(oxamate)-oxygen atoms occupying the axial positions of an elongated CuN2O4 octahedron. The values of the axial Cu–O interatomic distances are longer than those of the equatorial Cu–O distances, which is in agreement with the larger basicity of the carboxylate-oxygen atoms compared with the basicity of the carbonyl-oxygen of the amide fragment. The angles formed by the chelating ligands at the copper(II) ion are shown in Table .

The values of the axial Cu-O interatomic distances are longer than those of the equatorial Cu-O distances, which is in agreement with the larger basicity of the carboxylate-oxygen atoms compared with the basicity of the carbonyl-oxygen of the amide fragment. The angles formed by the chelating ligands at the copper(II) ion are shown in Table .

elements.content: Based on the values of the Cu–O and Cu–N distances around the copper(II) ion, the tetragonal distortion due to the Jahn–Teller effect implies an additional stability for this geometry. We assume that a monomer copper(II) species has never been observed due to the cis configuration of the bipy ligand around the copper(II) ion. This arrangement blocks two positions around the metal ion, and it does not allow the coordination of the carbonyl-oxygen atoms of the amide fragments (i.e., O1 and O6) from the oxamate ligand in trans geometry. It leads to a lack of tetragonal distortion, which induces the formation of the CP in which the distortion is observed.

We assume that a monomer copper(II) species has never been observed due to the cis configuration of the bipy ligand around the copper(II) ion. This arrangement blocks two positions around the metal ion, and it does not allow the coordination of the carbonyl-oxygen atoms of the amide fragments (i.e., O1 and O6) from the oxamate ligand in trans geometry. It leads to a lack of tetragonal distortion, which induces the formation of the CP in which the distortion is observed.

elements.content: The ligands play an important role in the crystal packing of 2. The amide hydrogen atoms of the H2edpba2– groups form a strong hydrogen bond with a water molecule (N4–H4···O7 distance equal to 2.995(5) Å; Table ), and its aromatic rings make a four-ring π-system with the aromatic rings of the bipy molecule (Figure ). This π-system is formed by a bipy-H2edpba2–-H2edpba2–-bipy set of aromatic rings with each bipy-H2edpba2– pair from neighboring chains involving symmetrically related copper(II) units. The average interplanar distances between the aromatic rings are 3.920(5), 4.132(15), and 3.920(5) Å, respectively. Crystallization solvent molecules also play a very important role in the crystal packing. There is a hydrogen bond network connecting the water and dmso molecules to the nearest polymer ribbon, together with intersolvent hydrogen bonds and very weak Car−H···O-type interactions involving the aromatic rings of the ligands that do not participate in the π-stacking (one aromatic ring per ligand). The four hydrogen atoms from one pyridyl ring of the bipy molecule interact with at least one oxygen atom in its vicinity, belonging to dmso, water, or oxamate (i.e., the free or coordinated oxygen atom from the carboxylate fragment). The aromatic phenylene ring of the H2edpba2– ligand interacts poorly with the nearest aromatic ring of bipy, which is involved in the four-ring π-system.

elements.content: This compound is a neutral copper(II) nonhelicoidal chain with one and a half crystallization water molecules per each copper(II) ion. It crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic C2/c space group. Each copper(II) ion is six-coordinate with a chelating bipy molecule and four oxygen atoms from two oxamate fragments of two H2edpba2– ligands building an elongated octahedral environment (Figure ), as observed in 2.

[Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅1.5nH2O (3b)

This compound is a neutral copper(II) nonhelicoidal chain with one and a half crystallization water molecules per each copper(II) ion. It crystallizes in the centrosymmetric monoclinic C2/c space group. Each copper(II) ion is six-coordinate with a chelating bipy molecule and four oxygen atoms from two oxamate fragments of two H2edpba2- ligands building an elongated octahedral environment (Figure ), as observed in 2.

elements.content: Each copper(II) ion in 3b exhibits a distorted six-coordinate environment and different chiralities [Cu1-Λ and Cu1ii-Δ, (ii) = x, −y, 1/2 + z] with the two bipy-nitrogen atoms and the O1 and O5 carboxylate(oxamate)-oxygen atoms building the equatorial plane and the O3 and O4 amide(oxamate)-oxygen atoms occupying the axial positions of an elongated CuN2O4 octahedron. As in 2, the axial Cu–O interatomic distances are longer than the equatorial Cu–O distances, which is in agreement with the larger basicity of the carboxylate-oxygen atoms when compared with the basicity of the carbonyl-oxygen atom of the amide fragment. The angles formed by the chelating ligands at the copper(II) ion are shown in Table .

elements.content: The linear copper(II) chains of 3b (Figure ) are interconnected by N–H···O (carboxylate) hydrogen bonds [N–H···O distances equal to 2.797(4) Å] and π-stacking interactions (Figure ). It is worth noting that the N–H···O type interaction is very common in the oxamic ligands, where it is at the origin of the formation of supramolecular dimeric species. The π-stacking interactions involve pairs of aromatic rings. The nearest H2edpba2– ligands from adjacent chains interact through the disordered aromatic ring. Both rings are disordered due to the possibility of rotation along the aliphatic −CH2CH2– unit of the flexible H2edpba2– ligand. The other main π–π interactions occur between one aromatic ring of the bipy molecule and the phenylene ring of the H2edpba2– group. The values of the average interplanar distance between these groups are 3.808(7) and 4.250(6) Å (3b). Very weak C–H···O type interactions involve the pyridyl ring from the bipy ligand that does not participate in the π-stacking. The carbonyl-oxygen atom from nearest chain and one water molecule also contribute to the stabilization of the supramolecular structure in 3b. The disordered phenylene ring of the H2edpba2– group also interacts with the same water molecule, and its disorder leads to the disorder of the water molecule.

elements.content: A comparison between the crystal packing of 3b and 2 shows that an effective interchain packing occurs in 2 because of the presence of a four-ring π-system. This four-ring π-system is lacking in 3b because the hydrogen bond between the amide hydrogen and the free carboxylate(oxamate)-oxygen atom shifts the chains and prevents their formation.

elements.content:
The identity of the single-crystal samples and bulk materials has also been confirmed through a comparison of the simulated and experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns (see the ).

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic properties of 3a and 3b in the form of χM T versus T plots [χM is the magnetic susceptibility per one mole of copper(II) ions] are shown in Figure S10 in the and Figure , respectively. Given that the magnetic properties of the two compounds are very similar, we focus here only on those of compound 3b. The values of χM T for 3b remain essentially constant from room temperature to ca. 30 K, and they are in agreement with the presence of magnetically isolated spin doublets. The χM T values exhibit a smooth decrease at temperatures below 30 K and attain a value of 0.33 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.9 K. No maximum of χM is observed in the temperature range investigated. The shape of the plot is typical of the occurrence of very weak antiferromagnetic interactions between spin doublets. This behavior was observed by our group in a parent copper(II) chain containing 2,2′-bipy and an oxamate as ligands.

elements.content: The magnetic data of the copper(II) chain of 3b was analyzed through the theoretical expression proposed by Hall for uniform chains of spin doublets (eq ) χ M = ( N β 2 g 2 / k T ) [ A / B ] with A = 0.25 + 0.14995 x + 0.30094 x 2 and B = 1 + 1.9862 x + 0.68854 x 2 + 6.0626 x 2 and with the spin Hamiltonian being defined as H = −J ∑ i S i · S i+1 and x = |J|/kT. This expression was derived from the numerical results of Bonner and Fisher, and it has been widely used for the treatment of the magnetic data of isotropic copper(II) chains. The best fit parameters obtained from eq are J = −0.40 cm–1, g = 2.13, and R = 1.1 × 10–5 [R is the agreement factor defined as ∑[(χM T)exp – (χM T)calcd]2/∑[(χM T)exp]2]. The same quality fit was obtained by treating the magnetic data through the above Curie law expression with values of g = 2.13 and θ = −0.29 K.

elements.content: The values of the very weak intrachain antiferromagnetic interaction (J = −0.44 cm–1) reflect the poor overlap between the magnetic orbitals involving the unpaired electron at each copper(II) ion through the extended dideprotonated H2edpba2– ligand. The unpaired electron is essentially located in the equatorial plane of each copper(II) ion in the d(x 2–y 2)-type orbital (with the x and y axes being roughly defined by the Cu–Nbipy bonds). The very weak spin density in axial [O3/O10 and O4/O9] sites and the long multiatom exchange pathway through the H2edpba2– skeleton, with values of the copper–copper separation of ca. 8.308 Å, account for the very poor overlap between adjacent magnetic orbitals and consequently for the observed weak intrachain magnetic interactions.

elements.content: On the basis of a flexible organic linker based on oxamate and 2,2′-bipyridine, we have synthesized and characterized three new compounds, one mononuclear nickel(II) complex (1) and two copper(II) CPs (2 and 3a, 3b). The mononuclear nickel(II) complex 1 forms a supramolecular chain built by hydrogen bonds. Attempts to synthesize this system by the reaction of 1 with Cu2+ ions resulted in the displacement of the nickel(II) ion to favor the synthesis of the copper(II) chains 2 and 3a. Compound 2 was obtained as nonrepresentative single crystals appropriate for X-ray diffraction experiments, whereas 3a was obtained as a polycrystalline powder. Single crystals of 3b were grown directly using a copper(II) precursor, and its crystal structure was determined by X-ray diffraction. The comparison between the calculated X-ray powder diffraction of 3b and the experimental results of 3a indicates that they are the same compound. Essentially, the chains 2 and 3b possess the same configuration; however, they present distinct crystal packings because of differences in the amount of crystallization molecules. Four aromatic rings are involved in the π–π stacking interactions in 2, whereas only two rings with additional hydrogen bonds occur in 3b. The variable-temperature magnetic study shows the occurrence of a very weak intrachain antiferromagnetic coupling in 3b, which is expected because of the long intrachain metal–metal distance.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

On the basis of a flexible organic linker based on oxamate and 2,2'-bipyridine, we have synthesized and characterized three new compounds, one mononuclear nickel(II) complex (1) and two copper(II) CPs (2 and 3a, 3b). The mononuclear nickel(II) complex 1 forms a supramolecular chain built by hydrogen bonds. Attempts to synthesize this system by the reaction of 1 with Cu2+ ions resulted in the displacement of the nickel(II) ion to favor the synthesis of the copper(II) chains 2 and 3a. Compound 2 was obtained as nonrepresentative single crystals appropriate for X-ray diffraction experiments, whereas 3a was obtained as a polycrystalline powder. Single crystals of 3b were grown directly using a copper(II) precursor, and its crystal structure was determined by X-ray diffraction. The comparison between the calculated X-ray powder diffraction of 3b and the experimental results of 3a indicates that they are the same compound. Essentially, the chains 2 and 3b possess the same configuration; however, they present distinct crystal packings because of differences in the amount of crystallization molecules. Four aromatic rings are involved in the π-π stacking interactions in 2, whereas only two rings with additional hydrogen bonds occur in 3b. The variable-temperature magnetic study shows the occurrence of a very weak intrachain antiferromagnetic coupling in 3b, which is expected because of the long intrachain metal-metal distance.

elements.content: These results indicate that (i) it is possible to obtain the same coordination polymer using different synthetic routes and precursors; (ii) only the copper(II) CPs and not the mononuclear copper(II) species have been obtained, which is most likely because of the lack of additional stability caused by the Jahn–Teller effect in the latter species; (iii) the metal ions play relevant roles in the self-assembly of their final topologies; and (iv) the ligand H2edpba2– is very versatile because it adopts either chelating or bridging coordination modes toward the metal ions.
elements.clean_text: These results indicate that (i) it is possible to obtain the same coordination polymer using different synthetic routes and precursors; (ii) only the copper(II) CPs and not the mononuclear copper(II) species have been obtained, which is most likely because of the lack of additional stability caused by the Jahn-Teller effect in the latter species; (iii) the metal ions play relevant roles in the self-assembly of their final topologies; and (iv) the ligand H2edpba2- is very versatile because it adopts either chelating or bridging coordination modes toward the metal ions.

elements.content:
These outcomes open several possibilities of tailoring molecules in the solid state by means of crystal engineering and supramolecular chemistry to achieve the desired products.

Crystallographic drawings of the chain structures of 1, 2, and 3b (Figures S1–S3), TG and DTA plots for 1, 3a, and 3b (Figures S4, S5, and S6, respectively), X-ray crystallographic data in CIF format for 1, 3a, and 3b (Figures S7 and S8), UV–vis of 3a and 3b (Figure S9), IR spectra of 3a and 3b (Figure S10), and χM T versus T of 3a (Figure S11). Crystallographic data for the structures of 1, 2, and 3b in CIF format. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org. Crystallographic data for the structures of 1, 2, and 3b have been deposited at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre with CCDC with reference numbers , , and , respectively.

The addition of [Ni(bipy)Cl2]·H2O (0.532 g, 1.75 mmol) dissolved in 50 mL of water to an aqueous solution (50 mL) of K2(H2edpba) (0.757 g, 1.75 mmol) produces a precipitate that was solubilized by adding 50 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide. The clear green solution was allowed to concentrate at room temperature in a hood. Nonrepresentative pale green prismatic crystals of 2 suitable for X-ray diffraction experiments were collected from a green polycrystalline powder (3a) after 3 weeks. The structure of 2 was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. The compound 3a was collected on filter paper and dried in the open air. Yield: 21%. Anal. Calcd for C28H26CuN4O8 (3a): C, 55.95; H, 4.19; N, 9.32; Cu, 10.57. Found: C, 55.81; H, 3.81; N, 9.19; Cu, 10.81%. IR/cm-1: 3490 and 3420 (O-H), 3360 and 3240 (N-H), 1678 and 1642 (CO), 1520 and 1440 (CN + CC).

[Cu(bipy)(H2edpba)] n ⋅1.5nH2O (3b)

This compound was obtained as follows: [Cu(bipy)Cl2] (0.015 g, 0.052 mmol) dissolved in 2.0 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide was introduced in a test tube; then, 10 mL of a 1:1 dmso:water (v/v) mixture was slowly poured into the tube; finally, 2.0 mL of an aqueous solution of K2(H2edpba) (0.028 g, 0.065 mmol) was added dropwise. The resulting solution was allowed to diffuse at room temperature, and X-ray quality sky blue needles were grown after 4 weeks. Yield: 71%. Anal. Calcd for C28H26CuN4O8 (3b): C, 55.95; H, 4.19; N, 9.32; Cu, 10.57. Found: C, 56.08; H, 3.86; N, 9.28; Cu, 10.92%. IR/cm-1: 3490 and 3420 (O-H), 3360 and 3240 (N-H), 1678 and 1642 (CO), and 1520 and 1440 (CN + CC).

cln_elements.content:
The identity of the single-crystal samples and bulk materials has also been confirmed through a comparison of the simulated and experimental powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns (see the ).

Magnetic Properties

The magnetic properties of 3a and 3b in the form of χM T versus T plots [χM is the magnetic susceptibility per one mole of copper(II) ions] are shown in Figure S10 in the and Figure , respectively. Given that the magnetic properties of the two compounds are very similar, we focus here only on those of compound 3b. The values of χM T for 3b remain essentially constant from room temperature to ca. 30 K, and they are in agreement with the presence of magnetically isolated spin doublets. The χM T values exhibit a smooth decrease at temperatures below 30 K and attain a value of 0.33 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.9 K. No maximum of χM is observed in the temperature range investigated. The shape of the plot is typical of the occurrence of very weak antiferromagnetic interactions between spin doublets. This behavior was observed by our group in a parent copper(II) chain containing 2,2′-bipy and an oxamate as ligands.
